object.property:
RemoteBox (ex. artwork) Copyright © 2010-2022 Ian Chapman RemoteBox is not affiliated with Oracle. All trademarks belong to their respective owners.
If you like RemoteBox or have found it useful, please consider donating.
RemoteBox is a client for managing VirtualBox and its guests over the network. For use with VirtualBox 6.1.x
Donate or visit the RemoteBox site
Icons are included which originate from the VirtualBox Open Source Edition, released under the GPL
Enter the decryption password for the specified medium
The hosts IP address for this adapter
The hosts network mask for this adapter
The hosts IPv6 address for this adapter, if IPv6 is supported
The hosts IPv6 network mask length for this adapter, if IPv6 is supported
The address of the DHCP server assigned to this host-only adapter
The netmask of the DHCP server assigned to this host-only adapter
The lowest IP address which will be allocated by the DHCP server
The highest IP address that will be allocated by the DHCP server
Set the group membership for the guest. Groups are dynamically created and destroyed as needed
Subgroups must be separated with '/'. Example: /GroupA/SubGroup/SubSubGroup New groups are dynamically created and empty groups automatically destroyed.

Deleting the hard disk image will permanently remove it from the host's file system. It will no longer be available in VirtualBox and all data on the disk image will be destroyed. Removing will make the hard disk image unavailable to VirtualBox, however it may be added again at a later date.
ACPI request to shutdown cleanly. Requires OS support

Choose whether to remove the guest and delete the associated files or only remove it from VirtualBox. Deleting all files is a permanent and irreversible operation. Removing will allow you to add the guest again at a later date
An absolute full path to the shared folder. The path must be accessible by the server
The name of shared folder as referenced by the guest
When checked, the guest will not be able to write to the folder
When checked, the guest will attempt to mount the folder on startup
Make this share a non-transient share
Name of the new hard disk and its location. Do not add a file extension
Chose the location and filename of the disk image copy
Chose the location and filename to move the image to
The default path where guests are created. This location must be accessible by the server.
The default VRDP (Remote Display) authentication library to use. The library must be accessible by the server * Do not specify the .dll or .so suffix. * If unsure, specify VBoxAuth
Reset the Machine Folder to the default value
Choose the default folder on the server for new guests
Permits the use of alternative hypervisors alongside VirtualBox * Disable if your server runs other hypervisors * Enable if your server only runs VirtualBox

Folder containing the autostart database. * Server configuration is required for this option. See the RemoteBox manual * The autostart database folder should be set the same as the server's configuration
Choose the location of the autostart database folder on the server
Reset the VRDP Authentication Library to the default

row.col: Keep all network adapter MAC addresses
Keep only NAT network adapter MAC addresses
Generate new MAC addresses for all network adapters

object.property: * All States : Includes any associated snapshots in the clone * Current State Only: Clones the current state, not any associated snapshots * Linked: Takes a snapshot of the original guest and links it to the clone
Choose how MAC addresses are handled during cloning
Don't change the disk names during cloning
Don't change hardware UUIDs during cloning
Resolution depth. Higher depths mean more colours

row.col: VirtualBox VGA Card with VMware SVGA II extensions
Include all network adapter MAC addresses
Include only NAT network adapter MAC addresses
Strip all MAC addresses for all network adapters
Keep all network adapter MAC addresses
Keep only NAT network adapter MAC addresses
Generate new MAC addresses for all network adapters

object.property: The full path and filename of the OVA/OVF appliance to import
Choose the OVA/OVF appliance to import
Hard drive images will be converted to VDI on import.
Choose how MAC addresses are handled on import
Save the log to a text file
The size of floppy disk image to create
Name of the floppy disk image. Do not append an extension
Choose the location and filename of the floppy image
Preformat the floppy disk with the FAT filesystem

row.col: VHD (Virtual PC / Hyper-V Virtual Hard Disk)

object.property: Disk image format to use * If unsure, select VDI (VirtualBox Format)
Allocates the entire disk size from the start. The image takes longer to create but is often faster to use than dynamically allocated images * Recommended when maximum disk performance is required
Splits the hard disk image into 2GB chunks. * Recommended only if the hard disk image will be stored on a filesystem that doesn't support >2GB files

Hard disk image is thin provisioned. The image will increase in size as the guest consumes space but does not require the entire disk to be allocated from the start * If unsure, choose dynamically allocated
Name of the hard disk image. Do not append an extension
Choose the location and filename of the HD
Disk image format to use * If unsure, select VDI (VirtualBox Format)
Allocates the entire disk size from the start. The image takes longer to create but is often faster to use than dynamically allocated images * Recommended when maximum disk performance is required
Splits the hard disk image into 2GB chunks. * Recommended only if the hard disk image will be stored on a filesystem that doesn't support >2GB files

The hard disk image is thin provisioned. The image will increase in size as the guest consumes space but does not require the entire disk to be allocated from the start * If unsure, choose dynamically allocated
Name of the new hard disk and its location. Do not add a file extension
Chose the location and filename of the disk image copy
The unique name of the guest
The operating system family the guest will run
The version of the operating system the guest will run
Deselect if this guest does not require a hard disk
Create a new hard disk image
Size of the allocated hard disk.
The image format to use. * If you are unsure, select VDI (VirtualBox Format)
Allocates the entire disk size from the start. The image takes longer to create but is often faster to use than dynamically allocated images * Recommended when maximum disk performance is required

Splits the hard disk image into 2GB chunks. * Recommended only if the hard disk image is stored on or will be transferred to an old filesystem such as FAT which does not support files bigger than 2GB.

The hard disk image is thin provisioned. The image will increase in size as the guest consumes space but does not require the entire disk to be allocated from the start * If you are unsure, choose a dynamically allocated image
Attach an existing hard disk image
The existing hard disk image to attach
The name of the port forwarding rule
The protocol of the portforwarding rule
The port number of the host to port forward
The guest IP to portforward to
The port number on the guest to portforward to
The IP of the host to portforward
The name of the port forwarding rule
The protocol of the portforwarding rule
The port number of the host to port forward
The guest IP to portforward to
The port number on the guest to portforward to
The IP of the host to portforward
Name assigned to this NAT network
Network and mask definition in CIDR format
Determines whether this network supports DHCP
Determines whether this networks supports IPv6
Determines whether this network should be advertised as the default IPv6 route, if IPv6 is enabled
List of active IPv4 portforwarding rules on this NAT network
Add a new IPv4 NAT portforwarding rule
Remove the selected IPv4 NAT portforwarding rule
List of active IPv6 portforwarding rules on this NAT network
Add a new IPv6 NAT portforwarding rule
Remove the selected IPv6 NAT portforwarding rule
Default action to take when the stop button is pressed
Automatically add the guest additions ISO to the VMM when connecting to a server
Sort the guest list alphabetically otherwise use the natural order
Automatically open the display to a guest when it's started
Desired display width. This value is used for auto-hints and with the %X substitution
Desired display height. This value is used for auto-hints and with the %Y substitution

Sends a resolution hint to the guest in order to set the screen resolution to the desired size. In general this method is unreliable and the best place to set the screen resolution is by using %X and %Y substitutions with the RDP client
Server hostname %h, Guest name %n, Guest OS %o, RDP / VNC Port %p, Password %P, Username %U, Auto-Hint Resolution (X, Y, Depth) %X, %Y, %D
The command to call when making RDP connections to guests. * Choose a preset or customize your own command * Consult the manual for details of % variables substitutions
Select an RDP client preset, or customize your own command
The command to call when making VNC connections to guests. * Choose a preset or customize your own command * Consult the manual for details of % variables substitutions
Select a VNC client preset, or customize your own command
Desired display depth. A higher depth provides more colours but may be slower and use more bandwidth. This value is used for auto-hints and with the %D substitution
Connect using this password. Leave empty if password authentication is disabled on the server
If enabled, SSL certificates must pass verification in order for the connection to proceed. You probably want to disable this option if your server uses self-signed certificates.
The URL of the VirtualBox server. For example http://myserver:18083
The user to connect as. Leave blank if authentication is disabled on the server
Current directory location on the remote server
Refresh the contents of the current directory
List of files in the current directory
Current file selection on remote server
The name of the USB filter
The vendor ID filter. Enter the hex number or leave empty to match any
The product ID filter. Enter the hex number or leave empty to match any
The revision filter. Enter the number or leave empty to match any
The manufacturer filter string. An exact match is performed on this string. Leave empty to match any
The product filter string. An exact match is performed on this string. Leave empty to match any
The serial number filter string. An exact match is performed on this string. Leave empty to match any
Defines the host USB port to match. Leave empty to match any port
Apply the filters to both, local only or remote only USB devices
The list of available Host-Only networks
The list of available NAT networks

Modify the medium format: * Normal - Standard format for hard disks * Immutable - Changes to disk are discarded on guest start * Writethrough - Directly attached, snapshots are not taken * Shareable - Enables concurrent use (eg clustered disks) * Multi-Attach - Like Immutable but guests maintain their changes
If the medium is attached to a guest, you may need to release it before modifying its type.
New virtual size of the hard disk image
Increase the virtual hard disk size * Shrinking the hard disk size is not supported * You may still need to increase the file system in the guest
Location and filename on the server where the appliance will be saved * Location must be absolute and writable * Do not specify the file extension
Choose where to save the appliance on the server
Include any attached ISO files in the exported appliance
Choose how MAC addresses are handled on export
The name of the product's vendor
The URL of the product's vendor
The version of the appliance or product
Description of the product or appliance
License text for the product or appliance
The name of the appliance * It's recommended you don't leave this empty
The name this snapshot should be given
<small>Some settings may require a power cycle of the guest to take effect</small>
The operating system family the guest is running
The operating system version the guest is running
Describes how clipboard data may be shared between guest and host.
The type of shutdown to perform on the guest when the host is shutdown
Number of seconds to wait before starting this guest on boot
Automatically start this guest when the host boots.
Choose the snapshot folder on the server
Location of the snapshot folder for this guest * Cannot be changed if the guest already has snapshots * Set to empty to reset to the default
Set the description of the guest
Selects the cipher to use for encrypting disks
Provides IO APIC to the guest * Required for 64bit operating systems * Required if 2 or more CPUs are assigned to a guest * Caution: For Windows guests, do NOT disable after installation
Use EFI instead of BIOS. EFI must be supported by the guest operating system. * EFI is required for Mac OS X * For other operating systems EFI is not recommended
The hardware clock of the guest is set to use UTC otherwise local time will be used. * UNIX and Linux generally expects UTC * Windows and DOS generally does not use UTC
Defines the chipset this guest will see. * PIIX3 is recommended for most operating systems * ICH9 is experimental. Recommended only for Mac OS X * IO APIC must be enabled for the ICH9 chipset
Defines the device boot order. Booting will only be attempted from enabled devices. Use the arrows to change the device boot order
Selects the emulated pointing device the guest will see. * USB options require USB support to be enabled * If unsure choose PS2 Mouse
Selects the emulated keyboard the guest will see. * USB options require USB support to be enabled * If unsure choose PS2 Keyboard
Amount of memory assigned to the guest
Amount of memory assigned to the guest
Makes Physical Address Extensions and NX available to the guest * Requires OS support but most support PAE * Allows 32bit guests to address more than 4GB
The number of virtual CPUs assigned to the guest. * 2 or more CPUs require hardware virtualization * 2 or more CPUs require IO APIC to be enabled
Allow CPUs to be hot plugged or hot removed from this guest. Hot plugging must be supported by the guest operating system
Restricts the amount of CPU time a guest can use. * Caution: Restricting CPU execution time may cause timing problems in the guest
Enable nested hardware virtualization on processors which are supported

A delta time to run the guest clock ahead of the host clock. Guest additions will honour this offset when using time synchronisation. * Default is 0. Correct guest and timezone configuration should not require this to be changed

When running many similar guests, Page Fusion can reduce the amount of host memory consumed. * Not supported on 32bit hosts * Not supported on hosts running Mac OS X. * Only supported for guests running Windows 2000 or newer
Provides your guest with a high precision time source * The HPET requires support from the guest OS
Large pages can increase performance slightly if your operating system supports them * Requires a 64bit host operating system * Requires Nested Paging to be enabled
The interface to use for Paravirtualization. * If unsure, select Default
Enables Nested Paging (EPT) which can increase performance if your host CPU supports it * If unsure, enable Nested Paging
If VPID is not supported by your CPU, this option will be ignored. * If unsure, enable VPID
The amount of time to wait at the BIOS screen. * Default is 0
Enable or disable the "fade out" effect for the BIOS logo
Enable or disable the "fade in" effect for the BIOS logo
Choose the BMP image on the server

Use an alternative image file for the BIOS logo. The image format is VERY specific. * It must be 640x480 in exactly 256 colours (8 bit) * It must be saved without colourspace information * It must be an uncompressed Windows 3.1x BMP file format * The image file must be accessible by the server at the specified path * Set to empty to revert to the default logo
Enable 2D video acceleration. * Effective only on Windows guests
Enable 3D (OpenGL or Direct X) hardware acceleration * Acceleration may not function over RDP connections * Only supported for Windows, Linux and Solaris guests
Configures the type of virtual graphics card. * If unsure, choose VirtualBox VGA
Amount of video memory assigned to the guest * Consumes host system memory not graphics card memory
Amount of video memory assigned to the guest * Consumes host system memory not graphics card memory
The number of virtual monitors assigned to the guest * Important: RemoteBox only supports connecting to the first display.
The number of virtual monitors assigned to the guest * Important: RemoteBox only supports connecting to the first display.
Enable the RDP or VNC server for this guest * Allows remote control and display using an RDP or VNC client * Requires the Oracle or VNC Extension pack to be installed.
Port range the RDP/VNC server will use * If unsure, use: 3389-4389
RDP authentication method. Does not apply to VNC display connections
Allows multiple remote display connections * If unsure, enable this option
The authentication timeout value. Does not apply to VNC display connections
Bind the RDP/VNC server to a specific IP address or hostname * If unsure, leave empty which means all IP addresses on the server
Record the guest's display or audio * Recording may may impact the performance of your guest
Record both audio and video, or select only either
The higher the audio quality, the larger the file size
Choose where to save the video on the server
Location and filename on the server where the video will be recorded * Location must be absolute
More frames per second produces smoother video at the expense of an increase in file size
More frames per second produces smoother video at the expense of an increase in file size
The higher the video quality, the larger the file size
The higher the video quality, the larger the file size
The vertical resolution (frame height) of the recording
The horizontal resolution (frame width) of the recording
The resolution (frame size) of the recording.
Storage controllers and media attached to this guest
The variant of controller to use
Use the host's I/O caching capabilities

Set the number of Controller Ports * Setting the port count lower than the number of attached storage devices will disable the storage in the guest * Too many unused ports may cause the guest to slow during boot
The device and port on the controller that the medium is attached to
When selected the disk appears to the guest as a solid-state drive (SSD)
Indicates a Live CD/DVD. The disc will not be ejected when requested by the operating system
Indicates to the operating system that this is a hot-pluggable disk
Toggles boot support for this controller
Select the drive mode of the floppy drive. * If unsure, 3½" 1.44MB Floppy
Assigns a virtual sound card to this guest
The host audio driver to use.
The virtual sound card to present to the guest * Soundblaster 16 is only recommended for very old operating systems
The codec the audio controller should use
Enables audio input (e.g. microphone) for the guest's soundcard
Enables audio output for the guest's soundcard. If disabled the guest will not output sound
Connect a virtual network card to the guest
Connect a virtual network card to the guest

How the virtual network card is connected to the physical network
* If unsure, use NAT or Bridged Networking * Bridged Networking is not supported for Solaris hosts when a WiFi interface is selected
How the virtual network card is connected to the real network or virtual network * If unsure, use Bridged or NAT
Name of host adaptor to use

In Bridged mode it is the name of the host's network adapter to connect to, otherwise it specifies the name of the Host-Only Network or the NAT Network to attach to. * Host-Only Networks and NAT Networks are defined in the VirtualBox preferences dialog
The name of the internal network
The name of the internal network
Sets the generic driver to use
Sets the generic driver to use
The MAC address of the virtual network card
The MAC address of the virtual network card
Plug or unplug the virtual network cable
Plug or unplug the virtual network cable
Sets the promiscuous mode policy of the network adaptor when attached to a host only network, bridge or internal network
Sets the promiscuous mode policy of the network adaptor when attached to a host only network, bridged or internal network

Enter the configuration parameters here for the generic network driver. They should be of the form:
name=value
Multiple parameters should be specified one per line

Enter the configuration parameters here for the generic network driver. They should be of the form:
name=value
Multiple parameters should be specified one per line
Working mode of the serial port. Disconnected means the guest will see it, but it will not be usable
Connect to an existing pipe or socket, or create a new one
Select the type of UART chip to emulate
I/O port address to use. Must be between 0 and FFFF
IRQ number must be between 0 and 255. * IRQs greater than 15 require IO APIC to be enabled * IRQs greater than 15 may require a 64bit guest OS
Choose a standard serial port or use customised settings
Try to automatically generate a suitable port / file path
Path to the serial port's pipe on the host when in HostPipe mode otherwise the host's serial port device name to use
Enable / Disable this parallel port. Note: Parallel ports are only support on VirtualBox hosts running Linux
The host's parallel port device name to use
I/O port address to use. Must be between 0 and FFFF
IRQ number must be between 0 and 255. * IRQs greater than 15 require IO APIC to be enabled * IRQs greater than 15 may require a 64bit guest OS
Choose a standard parallel port or use customised settings
Enable a virtual OHCI USB controller
The list of USB device filters attached to this guest
List of shared folders accessible to the guest
Add a shared folder. Folder path must be absolute
Changing Shared Folders explicitly saves settings
Power off the guest * Additional options are available in the button menu
Discard the guest's saved state * Equivalent to hard powering-off the guest
Open the guest's display * The guest must have the display server enabled in its settings and you must have a correctly configured RDP/VNC client
Send the Ctrl-Alt-Delete keyboard sequence or select an alternative from the menu
Available memory on the server. Press refresh to update
List of available guests. Refresh to see changes
History of messages including errors, info and operations
Save the message log to a text file. Useful for debugging purposes.
Summary of details about the guest
Additional guest information will be shown when selecting a guest * Extended guest information can make guest selection slower
The name you want to assign to the connection profile
The URL for the connection profile. For example http://myserver:18083
The username to use for this connection profile. Leave blank if authentication is disabled
The password to connect with. Leave blank if authentication is disabled or you want to enter the password at connection time.
Automatically connect with this profile when RemoteBox starts
Choose the medium to add. The location is from the point of view of the server
Copy an existing hard disk and optionally change its format
Move a storage medium to a different location
Modify the low-level hard disk behaviour or resize the hard disk
Release medium from guests. Media associated with snapshots will not be released.
Attempt to compact the hard disk image making it physically smaller. This operation may take a long time and use significant temporary disk space
Refresh the list of available media
List of available Hard Disk images
List of available optical disc images
List of available floppy disk images
The guests this medium is attached to
The encryption key of this medium
The unique identifier for this medium
